channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report E-2024070337
item.description:
Report E-2024070337

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-16
  • City: COLUMBUS
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal BCO experienced a UN2924 Silquest A-1101 Silane release from a 330-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2 ounces of product released to the metal tote body only. The plug on the top of the tote was missing which caused the release. The hole was plugged and a slosh test was completed which determined there would be no further release. The tote was wiped down, confirmed neutral, and confirmed secured for shipment on. The impacted pads and PPE were placed into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024070321
item.description:
Report E-2024070321

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-15
  • City: DES PLAINES
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XDP experienced a UN3265 Predator MR2516 release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1 ounce of product released to a 6” x 1” area of the tote lid. The tote was wiped down with pads and the surface was confirmed neutral. The cap was re-tightened and secured and a slosh test was conducted to confirm there were no further leaks. The impacted pads were containerized into a 5-gallon poly pail. The waste was stored onsite for terminal personnel to manage

  • Description: Shipment was accepted into NAC system on 7/12/24. Shipment was prepared for flight 722 on 7/15/24. During ULD build up the shipment was placed next to another pallet that had a nail protruding that was not visible at the time. This nail crated a small puncture in the bottom of one of the 20L drums causing a release on approximately 8oz of material.

item.title: Report E-2024070372
item.description:
Report E-2024070372

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-13
  • City: MANVEL
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR INWAY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 14, 2024, at 2057 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Manvel, Texas regarding the release of Hydrochloric Acid. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors investigated and confirmed that there was residual impact to a 4ft x 8ft area of the trailer floor caused by the previous release of 1 quart of HYDROCHLORIC ACID (UN1789, 8, II) from (1) 1-gallon jug. Contractors neutralized then cleaned the impacted area with absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste was containerized in (1) 55-gallon DF and taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070339
item.description:
Report E-2024070339

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-12
  • City: CONNERSVILLE
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Cari Mallett
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: the tanker was filled to capacity in order to get as much out of Amcor's tank as possible. Tanker has a capacity of 5350 gallons. On the paperwork it shows 5346 gallons was loaded. When material was brought to destinated facility to process the trailer dome was opened and a sample was taken to the lab. While the lab was analyzing the sample the dome of the trailer was laid down but not shut completely. The temperature outside was ~90F. The material in the tanker started to get hot and run out of the dome and onto the ground. 1 gallon of material leaked into secondary containment and was cleaned up in house. The cause of the spill was that the tanker was overfilled.

item.title: Report E-2024070340
item.description:
Report E-2024070340

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-12
  • City: CHARLOTTE
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ROADRUNNER TRANSPORTATION SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 12, 2024, at 0337 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Roadrunner personnel in Charlotte, North Carolina regarding the release of Callus Remover Eucamint. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 55 gallons of Callus Remover Eucamint (UN1814, 8, II) from (1) 55-gallon DF. The release was caused by a load shift and contained to pallets and a 6ft x 12ft area on the trailer floor. The load shift also damaged 2 more drums containing the same product, but without release. Contractors placed all 3 damaged drums into overpacks, then neutralized and cleaned the release using absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste was containerized in (3) 55-gallon DF’s and (3) 95-gallon DF’s and staged onsite by contractors for proper disposal.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 10, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3286 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately ten (10) gallons of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental Services (GES) to remediate the impacted site. The crew overpacked the damaged drum in one (1) 95-gallon drum. GES personnel utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the site. All impacted material was collected in one (1) 55-gallon drum.

item.title: Report E-2024070381
item.description:
Report E-2024070381

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-08
  • City: JEFFERSONVILLE
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 75000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On July 8, 2024, at 1745 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Jefferson, Georgia regarding the release of Caustic Soda Prills. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of Caustic Soda Prills (UN1823, 8, II). The release was caused by a rollover accident that impacted a 360ft x 50ft area of soil and an adjacent concrete lined drainage ditch that contained 635 gallons of free-standing impacted rainwater. Contractors collected the damaged cargo that was still in the trailer, neutralized and collected all free-standing liquid with a vac truck, excavated all impacted soil, then placed seed and straw. Contractors took 635 gallons of impacted rainwater in a vac truck and 11 roll-offs of impacted soil and damaged cargo offsite for proper disposal.

Hepaco did cleanup and repairs, Car Owner (Reagent Chemical) did leak test, and TRC Environmental Consulting did reporting

item.title: Report I-2024070004
item.description:
Report I-2024070004

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-18T15:13:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-22
  • City: GRAFTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FREEHOLD CARTAGE INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 2100
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Checking the transfer line, the associate noticed Van 53022 (FCI) was leaking onto the gravel. The associate notified the foreman and pulled the van onto the concrete roadway to get it off the gravel. We assessed the area and then we took the van to the CSF to be offloaded to find the leaking container. About halfway in the trailer we found the drum with a dime size hole in it and the contents had all leaked onto the trailer floor except for approx. 15 gal. We finished unloading the van and we processed the load. We cleaned the trailer floor with floor dry. We also cleaned the TL and the drive. The material that leaked onto the drive stained the concrete. The Transfer Line spill on the gravel was approx. 1 gal. it was contained in a 3 foot radius pot hole so we added floor dry to absorb the material. We took a before and after sample to the lab with the cin. (519142) we used on the drum that leaked. All effected areas have been cleaned. We generated 1 (1/4 Full) Tote. Tote is labeled with a Haz. Label with the info. needed and placed in the on hold area.

  • City: ATLANTA

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 10200
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: The IBC was strapped in the trailer by Heritage Crystal Clean (HCC). Heritage Environmental Services (HES) employees unloaded the trailer at the Heritage Transport (HT) transfer facility. HES employees loosen the load strap which exposed a whole in the body of the IBC. The whole was 1 inch or less in size. The whole was located approximately halfway down the side of the body. HES employees secured and blocked nearby storm drains and contact an emergency response contractor to mitigate the release, transfer the remaining contents of the damaged IBC to a new container, to recover the spilled material, and to containerize absorbent materials. The duration of the release was approximately 90 minutes.

ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and dispatched Hepaco to the site to assist with clean up. Hepaco responded and observed approximately 10-pounds of Cryolite released from the damaged plastic gaylord. The release impacted a 10’X23’ area on the trailer floor. No drains or soil were impacted. Hepaco recovered the Cryolite. Hepaco unloaded the trailer, used simple green rags, wiped down the trailer, freighted, and reloaded the trailer. Hepaco created one 5-gallon poly drum of waste. Hepaco left the waste on-site with the XPO dock manager.

Upon arrival it was noted that the road isolation valve was in the open position and the gas line closed with the equalizer open as well as the liquid vaporizer sample line was left open. These issues were immediately corrected by M&M and the leak was stopped.

The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel cleaned the impacted area and generated one (1) 5-gallon metal pail of waste. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070298
item.description:
Report E-2024070298

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-17T18:15:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-12
  • City: SHREVEPORT
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LSL experienced a UN1992 19122 Lacquer Thinner Fast release from (6) 5-gallon metal pails. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of product released to an 8’ x 10’ area of the trailer floor. The lids of the pails seemed to be leaking as a possible result of being stacked and crushed. The damaged pails were collected into an 85-gallon poly drum. Absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area. The impacted absorbents, pads, pallet pieces, and PPE were collected into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On July 5th, during the PM sort a pallet of drums was found leaking. The drums contained UN1263, Paint, 3, III. Two of the drums were damaged at the handles, one was damaged at the top chime, the last one was damaged at the bottom chime. The four leaking drums were placed into a steel salvage drums and amended shippers declarations were requested.

item.title: Report E-2024070299
item.description:
Report E-2024070299

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-17T18:15:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-05
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 5, 2024, one (1) 20-pound box of UN2277 was damaged by a nail and released approximately twenty (20) pounds of product to the truck interior. The monomer product experienced a polymerization reaction and damaged additional containers. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted site. Crews observed heat and vapor created from the polymerization process and contained and isolated the reacting product. All product was containerized into thirteen (13) 55-gallon vented poly drums. LSH utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted trailer and dock. All impacted debris and PPE were collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Hazmat was found at door 125 in the load end ready to go to the next load point. The outbound sort manager walked passed it and noticed a very strong odor coming from the box. QA was contacted immediately to inspect the box. I noticed a little wet spot on one of the bottom corners of the package and brought it over to the office in a lined tote for further inspection. The inner drum seamed to have a poor quality closure that caused some of the contents to spill out and make it a little noticeable to the naked eye. Once the package was fully opened, the corrugated liner seamed to be wet also to confirm that the hazmat was damaged and could have possibly been damaged while it was on the vehicle when the driver returned from the pick up but could have dried do to the Acetone & Isopropyl Alcohol ingredient that makes up the product.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 5, 2024, eight (8) 5-gallon pails of UN1490 were dropped during loading and released approximately fifty (50) pounds of product to the pavement. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE utilized hand tools and a HEPA vacuum to recover the released product. All damaged pails and impacted debris were collected and containerized into three (3) 35-gallon vented poly drums and one (1) 55-gallon vented poly drum

item.title: Report E-2024070030
item.description:
Report E-2024070030

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-15T18:15:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-01
  • City: SOUTH GATE
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: J. B. HUNT TRANSPORT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 3ft-by-5ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that thirty (30) gallons of material was released due to four (4) crushed 5-gallon plastic pails. The damaged plastic pails were placed into one (1) 30-gallon and one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. Clean Harbors personnel deployed a neutralizer to the impacted area and then used a granular absorbent to gather the spent material. The contractor placed the recovered spent absorbents into one (1) 30-gallon poly drum. One (1) 55-gallon poly drum was generated containing impacted pallet pieces. One (1) additional 15-gallon poly drum was generated for the contractor’s PPE. All waste generated from this response was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for J.B. Hunt contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070218
item.description:
Report E-2024070218

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-15T18:15:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-01
  • City: MENOMONEE FALLS
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A Veolia employee was offloading pallets of drums from a trailer at Veolia's 1- day intransit facility in Menomonee Falls, WI. In the process of offloading the trailer, the forks on the forklift extended past the end of the pallet due to it being a smaller size pallet. The employee was unaware of their surroundings and length of forks, allowing the forks to puncture a drum loaded in the truck behind the pallet that was being offloaded. Approximately 1/2 of a gallon of material leaked before the employee was able to secure the drum from leaking any further. The duration of the spill was approximately 30 seconds. The material was then cleaned and the employees reported the spill of material. The drum that was damaged with the forklift was overpacked for safe transportation to the disposal facility.

  • Description: PACKAGE WAS UNLOADED FROM TRAILER AND SENT TO QC AREA VIA BELT SYSTEM. DAMAGE INSPECTION: LEAKER, QC CLERK OPENED PACKAGED AND SAW INSIDE PAIL APPEARED TO BE LEAKING AND NOTIFIED A HAZ MAT RESPONDER. PACKAGE WAS THEN PLACED IN A LINED SPILL TUB. THE INNER CONTENTS IS A 5 GALLON PAIL WITH FEDEX HAZMAT SHIPPING PAPERS ON THE LID WITH A FLAMMABLE LIQUID 3 PAINT UN1263 LABEL THE SIDE OF PAIL.

item.description:
Report X-2024070736

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-12T15:12:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-09
  • City: BARRINGTON
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: DURING THE UNLOAD THE MANAGER NOTICED THAT THE PACKAGE WAS LEAKING AND ALSO WAS WET ALL OVER THE BOTTOM OF THE PACKAGE. IT WAS IMMEDIATELY TAKEN OVER TO THE HAZMAT CAGE TO SECURE IT AND VENTILATE IT. I WAS THEN CALLED OVER TO REPACK IT INTO A YELLOW SALVAGE DRUM IN A TIMELY AND SAFE MANNER. APPROXIMATELY 10 LITERS LEAKED OUT ALTOGETHER FROM THE 4 BOTTLES ON THE INSIDE OF THE PACKAGE. ONE BOTTLE HAS A PUNCTURE AND THE OTHER 3 BOTTLES HAD LOOSE CAPS WHICH IS WHY IT WAS LEAKING IN THE FIRST PLACE. WAITING FOR THE DISPOSITION FROM PGH NOW.

item.title: Report E-2024070201
item.description:
Report E-2024070201

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-12T15:12:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-08
  • City: N VERSAILLES
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Stephen Hudspeth
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On July 8th 2024, at approximately 11:30am, Union Railroad Train 50a was in the process of entering the Port Perry and Dexter Yards with a 96 car loaded iron ore train. The train was led my four locomotives. Brakes were applied to the locomotives only and allowed to release on the remainder of the train. This caused a great deal of force in the train that allowed the cars to leave the track. Rail dislodged during the derailment impacted the fuel tank of the third from lead locomotive causing it to spill its contents of fuel. Three of the four locomotives derailed as well as five of the 96 loaded ore cars. No other material was spilled, the remaining locomotives had no leaks. Internal responders were notified and responded to the derailment. The spill response plan was followed alerting the required agencies. A derailment contractor was called in to re-rail the train, and internal forces were assembled to repair the track. The liquid product on the ground was collected as quickly as possible into buckets, however most of the product entered the ballast and surrounding soil. The nearby river was monitored for signs of a sheen, inlets were checked but it was found the fuel had not reached either. A spill contractor was dispatched to provide lined dumpsters for the contaminated soil. The contractor also provided a vacuum truck to clean up the track area that could not be reached with an excavator. Contaminated soil was placed in the lined dumpsters. Dumpsters are staged for pickup when manifests are created and samples are analyzed. The area of the spill will be restored with new ballast. Any recovered fuel will be filtered and re-used elsewhere on the railroad. The locomotive with the broken fuel tank was checked in the morning and recorded to have about 900 gallons of fuel before the trip. 40 gallons were recovered from the tank before re-railing the locomotive. The maximum amount spilled would be approximately 860 gallons, however some of that amount was likely used in transit between the start of duty and the derailment.

  • Description: ABF states city driver Rafael Zawadzki (00933020) called safety at 08:15PM (CDT) about a hazmat spill that was not reported earlier in the day or cleaned by CURA. ABF driver stated that a bottle of UN2789, ACETIC ACID GLACIAL, 8 (3) PG II had spilled on the floor of trailer 401322 this morning. ABF driver stated that he began to feel lightheaded, nausea, shortness of breath, and headaches throughout the day he was delivering with the trailer. ABF driver states once he arrived back to ABF113, he notified Safety about the spill and his symptoms got worse. ABF driver reported his symptoms to Rodney Cooper (Operation Supervisor) and Rodney also stated he felt those same symptoms. ABF states during the call with Mr. Cooper, he informed Safety that his 4 other workers at that time (Rafael Zawadzki, Jason Granderson, James Fortin, and Joe Keefer) had also experienced these same symptoms. ABF Safety advised that at all costs, stay away from trailer 401322 until CURA had serviced it. ABF Safety immediately notified hazmat on-call at 08:43PM about the situation and on-call stated to do a spill report like normal and call CURA out to the scene ASAP. ABF Safety called CURA at 08:57PM and CURA dispatched a team to the location arriving at 10:26PM. ABF SCM Joshua Sabolcik states that they took one employee to Ascension Saint Joseph - Elgin Hospital (847-695-3200) and his 4 other workers to Advocate Sherman Hospital (847-742-9800) in Elgin, IL for treatment.

  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On July 2, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN1760 arrived on its side and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews uprighted the fallen tote, inspected it, and remediated it as required. TLE personnel utilized hand tools, cleaners, and absorbents to remediate the site. All spent absorbents and debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 35-gallon drum to be staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one (1) quart of material released from one (1) 1-gallon metal pail. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel cleaned the impacted area and placed the recovered material and damaged pail into one (1) 6-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070184
item.description:
Report E-2024070184

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-12T15:12:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-25
  • City: MANSFIELD
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: EnviroServe was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 6ft-by-8ft area of the trailer floor and 1ft-by-5ft area of the asphalt lot and estimated that three (3) gallons of material was released due to damage on two (2) 55-gallon metal drums. EnviroServe personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted areas and gathered the spent absorbents and placed them into one (1) 55-gallon metal drum along with impacted cardboard. The two 92) damaged drums were overpacked into one (1) 85-gallon metal drum and one (1) 85-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 3000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: UTLX 910980 was found by a carman during an inspection to have an odor of "propane". Local FD was notified and the immediate area of the leaking car was evacuated. FD arrived along with contractor Republic Services. Entry was made and Republic found a loose plug on the vapor valve and the vapor valve was opened about 1/4 turn. The valve was closed and the plug was taped and tool-tightened, mitigating the release.

  • Description: It was reported that 6-gallons of UN1263 Ultra Slow Pu Thinner LZC9264 was released from two (2) 11-gallon metal pails and 5-gallons of UN1263 WHITE HIGH-QUALITY PU SEALER was released from one (1) 11-gallon metal pail impacting the trailer floor. ERTS dispatched Haz-Mat Response Inc. (HMRI) to assist with clean up. HMRI located the spill and deployed absorbents to the impacted area. HMRI completed cleanup procedures and containerized the damaged pails, spent absorbents, and collected material into four (4) drums for disposal.
